courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Exploring the Earth System
courses.description: The course provides an interdisciplinary platform for students to navigate the Earth System Science curriculum. Natural phenomena associated with the atmosphere, hydrosphere, geosphere, cryosphere, and biosphere will be described, and concepts related to their dynamics and anthropogenic impacts will be introduced. The connection with global environmental change, natural hazards and the water-energy-food nexus will be highlighted. In addition to attending lectures, students will undertake visits to Museum of Climate Change and a geological field trip.

(3)To understand the science and technical challenges related to global environmental changes, natural hazards, and the food-water-energy nexus.
(4)To motivate students to self-learn, work in team and critically think about the Earth system, anthropogenic activities, and environmental problems.
(5)To facilitate students’ navigation of teaching and research in the Earth System Science Programme.

courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Solid Earth Dynamics
courses.description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the solid earth system stressing the geological, chemical, physical, and biological interactions among the lithosphere, hydrosphere and cryosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical concepts to explain the history and behaviour of the solid earth system. Geophysical and geochemical techniques for probing the interior of the earth are reviewed. Plate tectonics is introduced as a unifying theme to understand geodynamic processes. The course includes discussions of topics that are relevant to society, resources and sustainability, such as the physical and chemical basis of natural hazards (earthquakes, tsunami, landslides) and their mitigation, and the impact of geological processes on the global environment.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC2010 or ESGS2101.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will contribute to the understanding of the dynamics of the solid Earth system, specifically the lithosphere, hydrosphere, and cryosphere, as well as their interactions. The students should be able to: 1) describe and use the scientific process, explain how theories are built upon earth system observations, and how both are tested and revised; 2) explain how fundamental physical, chemical, and biological principles govern specific earth system processes, 3) participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussions of public policy related to earth system science, particularly with respect to natural hazards, resources, environment and sustainable development; 4) work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.

courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Climate System Dynamics
courses.description: This course presents an integrated introduction to the climate system, stressing the dynamics of the atmosphere and its physical and chemical interactions with the hydrosphere, biosphere and geosphere. The course applies basic scientific and mathematical principles to explain the history, current state and future projection of weather and climate, natural hazards (e.g., typhoons, floods), and global climate change in the context of natural variability and anthropogenic influence. Topics include Earth’s energy balance, climate feedback, convection and clouds, general circulation of the atmosphere and ocean, biogeochemistry and global carbon cycle, roles of vegetation and ecosystems, and historical and future climate change. Student taking this course are expected to have taken PHYS1111, CHEM1070 and MATH1010 or equivalent.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC2020 or ESGS2101.
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will contribute to the understanding of the dynamics of the climate system, specifically the atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere and solid earth, as well as their interactions. The students should be able to: 1) describe and use the scientific processes, explain how theories are built upon earth system observations, and how both are tested and revised; 2) explain how fundamental physical and chemical principles govern specific climate system processes; 3) participate knowledgeably and intelligently in discussions of public policy related to earth system science, particularly with respect to extreme weather events, global climate change and sustainable development; 4) work effectively in a team, and present information in a clear, concise and logical manner.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics
Introduction; overview of the climate system
Part I: Energy Balance of the Earth
Basic radiation physics; energy balance of the Earth; greenhouse effect
Simple climate model; radiative forcing, climate sensitivity and climate feedback
Lab 1: Climate sensitivity and feedback in a simple climate model
Climate variability and climate change; roles of aerosols; meridional structure of the atmosphere
Part II: Dynamics of the Atmosphere
Vertical structure of the atmosphere; Newton’s second law; pressure and hydrostatic balance; barometric law
Convection; first law of thermodynamics; dry adiabatic lapse rate; atmospheric stability
Potential temperature; water content in air; moist convection and cloud formation
Lab 2: Conservation of angular momentum on a rotating Earth
Coriolis force; pressure gradient force; horizontal momentum equations; geostrophic balance
Thermal wind balance; atmospheric fronts and jet stream; surface friction and ageostrophic flow
General circulation of the atmosphere; Hadley circulation in the tropics; baroclinic eddies and midlatitude weather systems
Lab 3: Introduction to weather analysis and forecast
Field trip to Hong Kong Observatory
Part III: Ocean and Climate
Overview of ocean circulation; Ekman transport and wind-driven circulation
Effect of Ekman transport on the interior ocean; western boundary currents; thermohaline circulation
Ocean heat buffer and transport; El Niño-Southern Oscillation; tropical cyclones
Part IV: Ecosystems and Climate
Fluxes in biosphere-atmosphere interactions; surface energy balance; evapotranspiration and photosynthesis; biogeophysical feedbacks
Biogeochemical reservoirs and residence times; carbon and nutrient cycling in ecosystems; geological carbon cycle
Contemporary carbon cycle; marine carbonate chemistry; biological bump; ocean biogeochemical feedbacks
Lab 4: Global carbon cycle
Global carbon budget; terrestrial carbon sink and biogeochemical feedbacks
Part V: Past, Present and Future Climate
Climate throughout Earth’s history; atmosphere of the early Earth; from Cretaceous to ice ages; recent 20,000 years
Recent climate change: observations and attribution
Future climate projections; impacts of climate change; where do we go from here?

courses.description: ESSC2110 is a fundamental field-based course introducing elementary concepts of past Earth’s processes and environmental changes. It also covers important aspects of plate tectonics, different rock types, geological deformation, geomorphology and environmental changes, natural hazards and human impacts. The principal goal of this course is to let students understand how the present geological records and landforms reveal the past tectonic movements and affect the human urban planning. Students are trained to observe, describe and discuss field features, with the help of field tools (e.g. compasses-clinometer and GPS receiver). Basic skills of field techniques, interpreting geologic maps and making field notes are introduced to assist students acquiring field data and discuss possible geologic processes. A field report from each group is required to summarize the field study logically. Field locations of this course may change from year to year. All students are welcome, but priority will be given to students who have taken ESSC1000.

courses.title: Biosphere, Climate and the Environment
courses.description: This course introduces basic concepts of the biosphere with a focus on its relationships with the Earth system and global environmental change. Topics include: ecosystem ecology; global biogeochemical cycles, climate and the roles of different life forms; evolution of life throughout Earth history; human perturbations of carbon and nutrient cycles; impacts of agriculture and deforestation; ocean acidification and eutrophication; responses and evolution of terrestrial and marine ecosystems and biodiversity under global climate change. Students are recommended to take ESSC2600 and MBTE2010 simultaneously.

courses.title: Continuum Mechanics
courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth system science applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations for fluids in a rotating frame; vorticity and divergence; geostrophic balance; boundary layer dynamics; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken ESSC4010 or EASC5010.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will acquire systematic training in continuum mechanics, a body of knowledge in mathematics and physics which is of critical importance in a diversity of earth system science applications, including geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography. The mathematical concepts are illustrated with geophysical examples. Students will be well equipped with useful background to pursue more advanced courses on physical aspects of earth system science.

Transformation of integrals. Velocity gradient, strain rate and vorticity.

Ideal constitutive relations: linear solid.
Elastic waves and elasostatics.

courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Structural Geology
courses.description: This course is an important part of the core Earth System Sciences Curriculum. It introduces the processes and products of rock deformation in three dimensions, ranging from micro- (micron) to macro- (kilometer) scales. It discusses geometries and mechanism of faults, folds, structural features of igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks, and superposed deformations and introduces regional deformational history and tectonics. Structural geology in the field of resource exploration (petroleum and mineral deposits) is also introduced. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise and demonstrations as well as field trips to local or overseas outcrops.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC3100. Pre-requisite: EESC2010 or ESSC2010 or permission of instructor.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to gain the following abilities:
1. Understand the geometry of different geological structures
2. Use concepts of solid mechanics to interpret the kinematics and geometries of geological structure formation.
3. Use graphical tools to compile and interpret structural data
4. Integrate topics in structural geology and plate tectonics through survey of scientific literatures
5. Make primary observations in the field and using them to construct and test structural hypotheses

Lectures focus on geometric, kinematic, and mechanical analysis of geological structures. Labs use geological maps, computers, stereonets, and physical analogs to illustrate these concepts. courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Global Environmental Change
courses.description:
This course includes the science behind the global warming issue, how the public views the issue and the critical thinking needed to analyze the evidence seen in the media/articles from the point of view of scientists. The world energy use, which is considered to be the cause of global warming, and the impacts are discussed in the course. In this course, students will learn about the radiation budgets/balance in the atmosphere, possible climate forcings that can upset the energy balance, how the earth’s global average temperature is measured, why global warming is described as “the biggest hoax” in human history, observations from the ocean and cryosphere and popular environmental issues/arguments discussed in the mainstream media. Newest observations from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) report are included throughout the course.

This course actively incorporates elements of innovation, design, global citizenship and social enterprisingness by asking the students to think innovatively but critically about possible solutions to adapt to and combat climate change and the global energy/health crisis. Different options including their pros and cons are actively discussed in class. Students are encouraged to think creatively about the problem from different angles, e.g., by standing in the shoes of climate skeptics – evaluating their “data”, how they present them, the arguments put forth by them – in order to develop a strategic approach to best communicate the issues to a variety of stakeholders. Project assignments will allow students to focus on one particular environmental issue in other part of the world, attempting to address the issue in the very different geographical, cultural, economic and political contexts from that of the students. Example projects can be “How to use geoengineering to combat climate change?”, “How can Sub-Saharan Africa secure its future food supply under the threat of climate change?”, etc. In the course, students will define and understand the problem. They shall form groups and discuss their own point of views and search information on the evidence of the corresponding arguments. They will present their ideas in class and write a self-reflection report. Each of the group will have to make an “infographic”- a layout of science knowledge learnt in the project that is easy enough for the public to understand but at the same time informative. Good infographics will be used in our OpenDay.

courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, the students will be able to
1) gain understanding of basic climate science behind the global warming issue, including how Earth’s global temperature has been measured by scientists and how the global average temperature is calculated
2) study observations from different components of Earth besides the atmosphere, such as ocean and cryosphere observations, and how these components are affected by the human activities
3) study how the scientific problem is presented and perceived in the society and learn how to use one’s scientific knowledge to identify possible solutions

The active incorporation of elements of innovation and design in the course is critical in allowing the students to develop a keen scientific mindset and logic flow to understand the complexity of the climate change and energy issues (Learning Outcome #1), and to dissect the reasons behind contradictory arguments in a society (Learning Outcome #3). Critical evaluation of the arguments from both sides (climate alarmists vs. skeptics) will ultimately allow them to develop their own stance in the issue, and think critically about the ways to move the world forward towards sustainability (Learning Outcome #3).

The incorporation of global citizenship and social enterprisingness is also crucial for students to develop a keen awareness of how environmental issues affect people in a huge variety of geographical and cultural contexts (Learning Outcome #2), and think critically about what kinds of solutions best fit a certain region (Learning Outcome #3).

courses.title: Solid and Fluid Mechanics
courses.description: This course presents the fundamentals of continuum mechanics illustrated with earth system science applications. Background materials on matrices, vectors and differential operators are first reviewed. The following topics will be covered: tensors and their properties; stress and strain; constitutive equations for Hookean elastic solid and Newtonian viscous fluid; mechanical properties and rheology of geomaterials; Eulerian and Lagrangian kinematics; momentum equations; vorticity and divergence; applications in geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography.

courses.learning_outcomes: Students will acquire systematic training in continuum mechanics, a body of knowledge in mathematics and physics which is of critical importance in a diversity of earth system science applications, including geomechanics, seismology, atmospheric dynamics, and oceanography. The mathematical concepts are illustrated with geophysical examples. Students will be well equipped with useful background to pursue more advanced courses on physical aspects of earth system science.

Vectors. Cartesian coordinates. Vector algebra.
Determinants. Change of orthonormal basis.

Conservation of mass. Conservation of momentum. Conservation of energy. Ideal constitutive relations: inviscid fluid. Bernoulli’s equation. Potential flow. Ideal constitutive relations: viscous fluid. Steady and non-steady flow.
Ideal constitutive relations: linear solid.
Elastic waves and elasostatics.

courses.title: Petrology
courses.description: Petrology is an essential subfield of Earth System Science because the rock record is the foundation for interpreting Earth history and internal processes. Petrologic concepts help us understand the Earth system, with connections to related fields such as geochemistry, geophysics, mineralogy, structural geology and geodynamics. This course broadly surveys the formation, distribution, chemical composition, mineral associations, and internal texture and structures in rocks of the earth’s crust and upper mantle, and establishes it relation to global tectonic environments. Class lectures are supplemented by lab exercise, demonstrations and tutorials (e.g. study of rock hand specimens, understand phase rule, use of optical microscope etc.).

2. Good knowledge of typical mineral assemblages of different rocks.
3. Use optical polarizing microscope to distinguish: (1) different minerals based on their optical properties, (2) typical igneous and metamorphic micro-textures and structures, (3) featured mineral assemblages corresponding to different P-T conditions.
4. Understand phase equilibrium and phase rule and their applications in understanding the rock forming process.
5. Understand different metamorphic facies and their significance of variable tectonic settings.
6. Use petrologic concepts and theories to address topics of societal interests, including natural hazards, natural resources, and human health issues.

The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principle, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Urban Climatology
courses.description: Human modifications to the surface of the Earth during urbanisation change most of the elements of climate and weather in the urban atmosphere. This course introduces the fundamentals of urban climatology and the processes caused by the changes in the surface environment, particularly focusing on how urban structures interact with the atmospheric environment. Numerical modelling and field techniques are introduced to understand the underlying processes resulting urban climatic phenomena. It also examines the implications on human comfort and climate-sensitive urban planning and design, as well as the relationship between cities and climate change.

courses.subject: ESSC
courses.title: Statistical Methods and Data Analysis for Earth System Science
courses.description:
This course covers the theoretical basis and practical applications of data analysis relevant for earth system science. This course aims to introduce students to Earth and environmental data manipulation, from sampling, reading and writing, to statistical analysis and parameter estimation, to time series analysis, to plotting and visualization. Topics include: digital signal processing, sampling techniques; probability distributions; hypothesis testing; correlation analysis; linear and nonlinear regression; statistical forecasting, harmonic analysis and spectral analysis; principle component analysis; and geostatistics. Tutorials will be based on real geophysical examples including remote sensing and in situ observations, as well as model data.

Previous elementary coding experience in Python 3 is recommended.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken EESC4510 or ESGS4004. Pre-requisite: (STAT1011 or 1012), and (EESC2030 or ESSC2030 or PHYS2061).
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will become knowledgeable about the acquisition, pre-processing and analysis of geophysical and environmental data, including remote sensing, in situ observation and model data. Students will acquire knowledge on techniques for data processing, including visualization methods and statistical analysis, and on the applications of these data and tools to geophysical and environmental problems. The students will develop: 1) the ability to evaluate an issue critically based on evidence and scientific principles, 2) to acquire knowledge effectively by self-study and using information technology, and to work independently, 3) to work effectively in a team, and 4) to present information in a clear, concise and logical manner. The students can also acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.

* Statistical Forecasting: Simple Linear Regression

* Statistical Forecasting: Predictor Selection, Ensemble Forecasting

courses.title: Remote Sensing – Principles and Applications
courses.description: Remote sensing observations are critical for monitoring regional and global changes, determining spatial and temporal variability of the Earth System, and addressing fundamental global issues. This course introduces the basic physical principles of remote sensing, including electromagnetic waves and radiation, optical, microwave, and non-imaging remote sensing. It also presents key concepts and examples on remote sensing applications in Earth system science (such as atmosphere, lithosphere, hydrosphere, cryosphere) and global changes. This course also provides computer-based lab exercises that facilitate the understanding of remote sensing principles and the processing of remote sensing data.

The students also can acquire a responsible attitude in study and work, and have motivation for life-long learning.
